awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020: Ecological drivers of disease  adaptation
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. When a pathogen infects a new host species, it can cause disease. The host species needs to adapt to this new threat through natural selection. The more disease-causing pathogens there are in the environment, the more adaptations it needs. Pathogen and disease abundance vary substantially between different ecosystems because of differences in temperature, precipitation, and other environmental conditions. However, the ecological rules and principles that govern pathogen abundance in specific environments are not well understood. These principles are critical to understanding how climate and human-wildlife contact impact human, agricultural, and wildlife diseases. To define the most important ecological principles of pathogen abundance, the fellow will integrate bat genomics and ecology to quantify adaptation to pathogens across ecosystems and species, using field sampling, genome sequencing, and computational methods development. This project can affect disease management and prediction of climate change impacts on pathogen spillover. Another major goal is to expand science participation of local underrepresented students by introducing them to science in their backyard, the Sonoran Desert.

Infectious disease results from host-pathogen interactions in an environment conducive to transmission. The resulting patterns of disease prevalence are driven by complex ecological interactions. By collapsing host-pathogen interactions into their integrated effect on the host genome as genomic disease adaptation, this project will develop the RoL describing ecological drivers of disease adaptation. This relates ecology to disease prevalence at three levels: across species in different environments (aim 1); within species across populations in different environments (aim 2); and within populations across time (aim 3). To do so, the fellow will sequence Myotis bat genomes across multiple ecosystems, develop a deep-learning pipeline to quantify selective sweeps in virus- and bacteria-interacting proteins, and correlate ecological characteristics with signatures of selection using GIS methods. The fellow will gain training in population genetics and methods development, and create methods and data resources. To broaden the impact of the work, the fellow will develop science outreach using native bat biodiversity and the unique Sonoran Desert to increase interest and science literacy in local first-generation, Hispanic, and Native American high school and university students, and recruit long-term research interns.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Climate is a major factor influencing the patterns of pathogen prevalence, and thus host exposure to pathogens, worldwide. Pathogen and disease abundance vary substantially between different ecosystems because of differences in temperature, precipitation, and other environmental conditions. However, the ecological rules and principles that govern pathogen abundance in specific environments are not well understood. When a host species is exposed to a pathogen, such as a bacteria or virus, it can become infected, resulting in disease. The host species can adapt to this threat through the process of natural selection. This adaptation can be used as a measure of pathogen exposure. This project used the genomes of host species to determine what viruses each species has been exposed to over its evolutionary history. This project combined this information with host species range data and climate data and developed a new statistical method to define the most important ecological principles of pathogen exposure across mammals. Bats in particular have a unique relationship with infectious disease, and have been previously shown to be more resistant to viral infection than are other mammals. This project further investigated the patterns of virus adaptation within bats, with major findings that may be crucial to understanding and better defining why bats are better at tolerating viruses than are other mammals.

 

We find that host species with ranges in regions with less precipitation seasonality experience stronger genomic adaptation to viruses. In other words, it is the consistency of precipitation throughout the year that is the driving force impacting virus exposure. In regions such as some tropical rain forests, where precipitation is more consistent year round, host species are more strongly adapted to viruses. While this is consistent with the generally accepted pattern that infectious disease has more impact in the tropics, this work shows that it is the regularity of precipitation, not temperature or overall amount of precipitation, that is driving this pattern. In addition, we find that diet also influences the strength of adaptation to viruses, with herbivores having less virus adaptation than carnivores. Thus, as climate change changes global patterns of precipitation, we may also see changes in the viruses to which host species are exposed. It is possible that host species living in regions that develop more highly seasonal climates will be more strongly impacted by shifting viral ranges.

 

Since bats are typically thought to be more resistant to viral infection than other mammals, we sought to understand what factors may be driving this important difference. To do so, we generated high quality reference genomes for 8 bat species found within North America, as well as sequenced over 150 additional bats from those species. We find that bats are strongly adapted to DNA viruses, but not to RNA viruses. This is in contrast to humans, in which RNA viruses drive most adaptation. We also find that other mammalian orders show a mix of adaptation to DNA viruses and RNA viruses. This suggests that bats are indeed unique in their response to viruses relative to other mammals. Bats may have been required to adapt to RNA viruses less often, and while the reasons are still unclear it could be related to to adaptations to other unique aspects of bat physiology, such as flight and their exceptionally long lifespans, or differences in exposure. During the course of this project, the fellow conducted science outreach with local high schools and local organizations using native bat biodiversity and the unique Sonoran desert to increase interest and science literacy in local first-generation, Hispanic, and Native American high school and university students. This included participating in Critter Nights at Mission Garden, mentoring high school students through the University of Arizona STAR labs program, and generating high school-level outreach materials.

 

Ongoing work by the fellow includes analyzing the 150+ sequenced genomes from these 8 bat species to determine the relative impact of habitat differences on virus adaptation within species. This fellowship helped the fellow to achieve the goal of securing an assistant professor position, where she will expand her research program to investigate the impact of species invasions on infectious disease in native species.
